content.description: This climb can be toproped from the same anchors as Mummy Dick. Heads up just right of the chossy crack, staying left on the wall. Be careful of the crack to the left, it is loose. Could be done as a very dicey trad lead, as the first 25 feet takes great gear.
content.protection: Toprope, access the anchors by climbing Mummy Dick.

content.description: Hand crack that follows questionable hollow sounding flake in a spot. Traverse left from crack to top out on loose rock. Runout to chains.
content.location: Starts on obvious hand crack to the right of Mummy Dick, on the other side of the fin. Rap from Mummy Dick's chains.

content.description: This route is not really part of the same wall, but is located at the same parking lot. Climb the finger crack up the short wall by the cattle guard, placing many small cams. Make sure to back them up. This climb is a little loose. Hopefully it will clean up with a little traffic. There to do if it looks appealing to anyone.
content.protection: Small cams and stoppers, chain anchors.
content.location: This route is located about 50 ft back downhill from the yellow cattle guard. Look for the finger crack on the small fin on the east side of the road.

climbs.name: No Animals Were Harmed During the Bolting of This Route

content.description: No Animals starts in a broken crack system with some loose rock, but good gear. Head directly up the wandering cracks to gain a small ledge. Place a couple of pieces here. Pull onto the next face for some fun moves on good rock, clip the first bolt, and then head through one more to reach the anchors.
content.protection: Single rack from #1 Metolius to 1", quickdraws, chain anchors.
content.location: This will be the second route that you see as you head up the hill. Belay from the small ledge built into the hillside. Start up the obvious crack system and head directly up to the upper face.

content.description: This route ascends the thin face at the base of the fin. Very thoughtful and sustained movement throughout the climb, with a little spice at the crux. After clipping the last bolt, climb a few ledges to the anchors.
content.location: This will be the first route you come to from the approach trail. Look for the bolts going up the small face to a ledge with anchors. Belay from the base of the fin.

content.description: Climb through a small overhang/cave and then pull around right onto the face. Vertical and sustained climbing then leads to a difficult red point crux involving a 1/4 pad, two finger crimp at the last bolt.
content.location: This route is at the very last that you will come to on the Style Wall. It is marked by a small cave, and 2 "seats" on a ledge.

content.description: The Mess shares the same start and first three bolts as The Devil Wears Carhartts. At the third bolt, step left (long stretch), then head up the small corner to a good rest on a small ledge. Depart the ledge to sustained climbing with good moves, then pull onto the upper bulge to hit the crux deadpoint move. Shares anchors with Gregathor's Victory.
content.location: This route starts off the large block on the right of the belay platform. Follow the bolt line, trending left to the small bulge at the top of the wall.

content.description: This route starts slightly uphill from the platform, and trends left up the wall on a left leaning "rail/corner". Thin and fun climbing that leads up to a stretch left (crux), then finished up a few easier moves. Great rock, be careful for a few rather sharp holds.
content.location: This route starts slightly uphill from the platform, and is the second route from the left in this section. Look for the bolt line that trends left to join up with Fashion Disaster, with which it also shares anchors.

content.description: This route gets the stars for the wall. From the platform, head directly up to the splitter crack. Very sustained and pumpy movement through the entire climb on amazing features and perfect rock. A very hard onsight as the climbing can be fairly thought-provoking. There is a short second pitch that goes at 9+ that will take you to the top of the wall. It can be linked with the first pitch.
content.protection: Quickdraws, 3 cams from .5 to 1" (in the obvious splitter), chain anchors.
content.location: From the platform located about 80 yds up the hill, this route heads directly up through the splitter crack in the wall. This is the 3rd route from the right and the center of the climbs in this section.

content.description: This route ascends the corner on the left-hand side of the wall. Do some tricky moves to get up to the left leaning rail around the second bolt, then head left to get into the major corner and up to a good stance. Finish on the upper face on some great rock. There is an optional short second pitch that goes on gear, and can be easily linked with the first one, watch for drag though.
content.location: This route is on the section about 80 yds uphill, from the platform near the big block. Look for the corner on the left side of the wall, this route is the furthest left in this section.

content.description: This route starts off the big block and heads straight up the wall following a system of sidepulls and pockets that seem to work your right arm. First, step off the block onto the face and do some thoughtful moves to get to the second clip. Head up good rock and cool features to the anchors. Sustained movement and dead vertical.
content.location: After hiking up the hill about 80 yds, you will reach a platform formed by a tree against a large block. This is the rightmost route of routes from this ledge. Start from the top of the block, and head straight up.

content.description: Begin in a shallow corner (protect with a cam) to a large ledge where you'll clip the first bolt. A powerful side pull will take you past a small tree to a slabby section. Next surmount a small roof to enjoyable climbing on the face above.
content.protection: 9 bolts and a half inch cam
content.location: Approximately 25 yards climber's right of The Devil Wears Carharts. Look for a line of bolts ascending the face about 30 feet downhill of a prominent right-facing corner system.
